events.target_title: Multi-seat support broken in 3.34.1

note.body:
I upgraded Fedora 30 to Fedora 31. Both multiseat and VNC stopped working.

I have two seats: seat0 and seat1 on the same WS. When I boot up my WS two login screen appears.
I can log in at seat0 and open the gnome session. But when another user tries to log in at seat1, no password screen appeared and the first user session at seat0 terminates.

If there are no users logged in at the seats and some user tries to open a network VNC connection, he can see the GDM login screen and enter the password. But his graphical gnome session starts at seat0 instead of network VNC.

I think the basic idea of changes in 3.34 that any user can have only one graphical session contradicts to the current multiseat and VNC implementation.

In a multiseat environment (in Fedora 30, because it does not work in F31)

loginctl

SESSION  UID USER SEAT  TTY 

      3 1001 oleg seat0 tty2

     c1   42 gdm  seat0 tty1

     c2   42 gdm  seat1     

3 sessions listed.


When someone opens a VNC network connection a new gdm session appears:

loginctl

SESSION  UID USER SEAT  TTY 

      3 1001 oleg seat0 tty2

     c1   42 gdm  seat0 tty1

     c2   42 gdm  seat1     

     c3   42 gdm            

4 sessions listed.


And when the user logs in to VNC, the session of gdm disappears and the session of the new user appears:

loginctl

SESSION  UID USER    SEAT  TTY 

      3 1001 oleg    seat0 tty2

      5 1002 larissa           

     c1   42 gdm     seat0 tty1

     c2   42 gdm     seat1     

4 sessions listed.

Copied text from rich text editors seems to be stored in the clipboard as a bitmap in X11

note.body: Merging !939 may result in a better default if text is available from the clipboard, but it will *not* resolve this issue. A clipboard manager should not suppress available types and offer a subset or request some "best type" and hand that over before a target application decided about the format it wants to paste.

events.target_title: Copied text from rich text editors seems to be stored in the clipboard as a bitmap in X11

note.body: If the clipboard manager is not transparent (i.e. offering all types the source application offers), it should not interfere with the clipboard at all as long as the source application is open and can be asked for the format the destination application wants. In the case of LibreOffice these can be internal formats a clipboard manager never will handle. If the source application exits, the clipboard manager should store and manage all formats the applications wants to store in the clipboard for further use by other applications. These must not be limited to text/plain or image/* offers.

events.target_title: Please add memory (M+, M-, Mr and Mc) functions....
Please add memory (M+, M-, Mr and Mc) functions....

note.body:
Hi Robert,

Thanks so much for the quick reply!

My use of the Memory function(s) is fairly simplistic: perform one calculation (say A / B), M+ the result, perform second calculation (say C x D), then multiply that result by MR.

Or to perform various multiple individual calcs, M+'ing (or M-'ing) the individual results to create a final answer, retrieve with a press of the MR button.

I guess that some of these things may be achieved via other methods (probably involving calc history and various additional mouse-clicks), but having individual buttons for these 4 functions makes number-crunching far simpler.

I've been having a look at other Linux calculator options, but the ones I found still had some drawbacks:

KCalc - probably one of the better ones, but the amount/size of required dependencies is a bit much (Linux Mint xfce 64-bit). It implements the M+/-/R/C functionality, pretty much in the exact way a physical calculator would.

galculator - Implements it in a slightly strange/non-intuitive way, as the 'buttons' don't seem to work as a real calc.

If it were possible to add the 4 buttons/features (M+, M-, MC and MR) in the same way as a physical calc, it would make things much more usable, for me and a few others - I've noticed that the lack of these functions is an issue for a number of others when looking at reviews/comments on other Linux calculator programs.

In regards to the questions you asked:

1: I guess the retention of the memory could be persistent, depending on a flag in preferences? One a physical calculator it typically is erase upon power-off, so this would be fine too.

2: #69 wouldn't really affect things (for me at least), since it's really the presence of the actually buttons (M+/-/R/C) that's required.

I understand that this may require a fair bit of additional programming and that you probably have a sizeable list of other features to implement, but it would be a nice addition to any future release. :-)

Once again, thanks for the reply!

Cheers,

Mike.

events.target_title: g_file_set_contents() can fill target with NUL bytes if it did not previously exist

note.body:
For your info. If you want to have a more reliable g_file_set_contents() an additional sync is needed: [0002-flush-the-metadata-of-the-rename.patch](/uploads/3dee7919dc6ac8b487ada615294a2158/0002-flush-the-metadata-of-the-rename.patch)

Something weird seems to happen when uploading patches, since it seems to remove the commit log:
```
While rename does atomically rename, it doesn't provide durability. So
flush the directory so the meta-data is on the disk as well, before
reporting g_file_set_contents was successfull, so even in case of a
crash the new contents will be there.

For our use case: embedded product with ubifs, which doesn't have a
workaround for buggy applications [1] that behavior is wanted. For
e.g. connman stores the Wifi password etc with g_file_set_contents.
When power cycling the device after entering the Wifi settings, the
entered settings should be used directly. Not after an unknown amount
of time.

[1] http://www.linux-mtd.infradead.org/doc/ubifs.html#L_sync_exceptions
```

events.target_title: Unable to login to Riot.im or custom server from Fractal
Unable to login to Riot.im or custom server from Fractal

note.body:
Okay, here's an update.

I'm able to login to the Riot instance from Fractal by changing the provider url from `riot.im/app` to `matrix.org`. (That make sense, since matrix.org is the identity server and riot uses it). Figured it out by playing around. Custom server is still out of the question. Planning to try with a self hosted one.

With that being said, the following are worth doing.
1. Updated documentation
2. Server validation in the "Provider" page.

Closing this issue.

events.target_title: French translation update + ‘New file’ feature
French translation update + ‘New file’ feature

note.body:
When you have a program which takes data from small binary files, you can create such a file using GHex with the ‘New file’ feature and the insert mode. It will likely be for testing purposes or to create a data file for an arbitrary program.

It’s also a handy feature to test GHex and to nurture the idea that binary files can be created and manipulated like a familiar document (as many reverse-engineering works suggest) — :wink:.

Anyway it’s only a few lines of code.

I hope you’re okay with other changes (described in commit messages) too.

events.target_title: French translation update + ‘New file’ feature

note.body:
Is there a guide somewhere that says how to deal with translations in this project? I commonly update all the PO files with new strings when there are new ones or for each release, so that translators can just pick the file, write their translations and submit the result, but it seems it was not managed this way before. Some PO files have not been updated during many years, e.g. help/it/it.po in master is based on a template from 2007.

GHex’s help is actually quite outdated too. I should work on it.

events.target_title: Bluetooth and Wi-Fi items in Power Saving are still ambiguous

note.body:
It is mainly not about the wording, and not about the menu usage at all, it is about the function in the background. And it is not about too much possibilities, the use case here is very common in "nomade" users and users work as contracted non-employee:

I am on battery and ssh-ing somewhere or open VPN connection.
When the power save activated, it turns off the wifi by default. 
The broken wifi connection successfully kills ALL of the ssh and VPN connections. The hanging up kills ALL of the processes running on remote end - e.g. tar-ing some very big directory turning my previous work to rubbish. So I WANT to disable the switcing off the wifi (and mightbe same for bluetooth)
The wording in Power management applet say "... can be ... off" - so one assumes when the button here is OFF, the power manager CAN'T switch off the wifi / bluetooth. 
Something like this should be done in the background:
```
wifi.powersave
NM_SETTING_WIRELESS_POWERSAVE_DISABLE (2): disable powersave
```

Instead the switch just switch off the wifi / bluetooth. The function for OFF here is meaningless as the intended switch off can be done in the GNOME somewhere else with much less effort, actually much easier.

And no, it is not about the too long list and function needs to be removed. It is just about implementing the function accordingly and undersating the background. 
If you think the function should not be here by any reason I do not know about, pls move the same switch to gnome-tweak-tools to prevent the necessary conf editing in the background.

In the use case described above, the "strong" and "middle" power savings are meaningless, I WANT to keep the wifi ON until there is any power.


Edited:
Actually the power saving sugegstions might be good idea in separate pop-up or pane or anywhere else, however removing the existing items instead of properly programming the functions just turning the system less usable.

events.target_title: Plug-in crashed: "file-png.exe" (C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\lib\gimp\2.0\plug-ins\file-png\file-png.exe)

note.body:
Same problem for me too. This is a real thing, in addition to other weirdness described below.

This is on a clean install of GIMP 2.10.14 on a new Windows 10 laptop. I used 2.8.x on my old laptop.

There are zero resource issues on this machine. I have memory and filesystem space to burn. "Resource Consumption" in Edit -> Preferences is set to very high values.

I'm getting "Plug-in crashed" error trying export to a variety of file types including tiff, png. Also: "Procedure 'file-tiff-save' returned no return values".

On rare occasions the export works; mostly it fails. On at least one occasion the export succeeded after a reboot, but then subsequently failed.

Perhaps this is related to the following very strange behavior, which is itself disturbing. Often on this installation I have difficulty starting GIMP using a variety of methods. Sometimes I will double-click the GIMP icon on my Windows desktop and nothing happens. Other times I will try to start GIMP by double clicking on a .xcf file in Windows Explorer. Sometimes I will try to open the .xcf file explicitly by right-clicking the .xcf file in Windows Explorer and then clicking "Open". Usually, but not always, GIMP fails to start.

Interestingly, if I keep trying, doing EXACTLY THE SAME THING multiple times, I can eventually get GIMP to start. For example, I might try to "Open" the .xcf file in Windows Explorer. Nothing happens. Wait 10-15 seconds, try again. Nothing happens. Wait some more, try again. Nothing happens. Try yet again. This time it starts. Very odd. There seems to be some intermittent failures (or, actually, successes) going on with launching GIMP, and perhaps also with the export plug-ins? Windows process-creation issues?? When trying to start GIMP I sometimes keep an eye on the processes in the Windows Task Manager to see if there's any sign of a GIMP processes trying to get going. There isn't.

The problem launching GIMP is not tied to any specific .xcf file. I've tried many. And as I said, attempting to launch by just double-clicking the GIMP icon on the desktop also fails.

events.target_title: Plug-in crashed: "file-png.exe" (C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\lib\gimp\2.0\plug-ins\file-png\file-png.exe)

Took a quick look at the Windows Event Viewer -- not something I typically do. I see nothing noteworthy. But there's a lot of stuff in there, and I don't really know my way around it. Looked at "Administrative Events" and "Windows Logs" but no entries got my attention. I also took a look at the Event Viewer right after the crash of an export plug-in and didn't see any significant entries around that time.

Speaking of the export plug-ins, they continue to sometimes crash and sometimes work, without any discernible pattern. For example, I just now had an .xcf open and tried four times in succession to export it to a tiff. In this test it actually worked the first three times and failed on the fourth. I used a unique filename for each export attempt: bbb.tif (ok), ccc.tif (ok), ddd.tif (ok), eee.tif (crashed).

events.target_title: add gretl.lang (or hansl.lang) to language-specs
add gretl.lang (or hansl.lang) to language-specs

note.body:
Hi, I'm from the gretl team (gretl.sf.net). Gretl has used gtksourceview for its built-in editor for a long time. We now think it would be good to distribute the gretl.lang file also upstream through you. Some questions about this:
First, how to proceed? Simply by attaching the file here?
Second, we're not sure about the naming. Gretl is a program, but it has a comprehensive scripting language which got the name "hansl" some years ago. Is it OK if the name id inside the lang file says "hansl", or should the file name then also be hansl.lang?  
Another more detailed question: To make the existing gretl.lang file work with gedit we had to comment out some sections referencing the external languages Stata and Ox. (Those languages enter the picture because we offer to have "foreign" language blocks embedded in a hansl script.) So far so good. But we could also contribute a stata.lang file. Would you like that or would you rather not have such closed-source software referenced?

If the new .lang file gets adopted, would it only be for version 4 or are there some updates still happening in version 3?

I've also read some things about a license statement that has to be included, is that right? 

Thank you,
Sven

events.target_title: Search support in conversion UI

note.body:
I would like to suggest a solution that could be added alongside the search support in case of the currency combos.

I believe this would improve usability of the long combo list for those who often use the Calculator for quick rate conversion between a number of currencies. I'm not sure if the same approach would work well for the units conversion.

**Proposed solution:**

Add feature to allow the user promote a list of favourite currencies to the top of the combo list, the "favourite currencies" would be defined through the Preferences dialogue.

These currencies would be then promoted to the top, in alphabetical order, with the remaining list of currencies listed below with the two parts of the list separated by a horizontal line, for example if we assume that "Euro" and "US Dollar" are marked as favourite, the combo would look like this:

```
Euro
US Dollar
---------
Algerian Dollar
Australian Dollar
...
```

This way we could access the most relevant / most common used items quickly, without having to scroll through the long list every time we need to select the currency pair.

events.target_title: gtk3 FileChooserDialog regression: typeahead searches the local filesystem rather than selecting the item matching the typed text

note.body:
Hello, I'm adding my voice here as well, _showing up_ so to speak.

I do not wish to use Gnome nor GTK3's FileChooserDialog, yet I'm forced to nonetheless, as many applications are built using the GTK3 framework. I'm of the opinion that this fact places certain obligations on you - this (at this point old) change affects not only Gnome Desktop, but also users of any other desktop environment, if they need to use an application built with GTK.

By enforcing this design decision in the FileChooserDialog and not just Nautilus, you are responsible for creating a huge inconsistency in the user interface. In the five years since you've made this change, as far as I can tell, nobody else adopted a similar change: Windows, KDE, Qt and Mac all just search the current directory.

It doesn't matter whether this search is good or bad when considered alone. The fact that you do something else that the user expects from everywhere else means you're doing the wrong thing.

Now, again in my opinion, this decision is awful even when considering Gnome only. You're punishing users for knowing where their files are. It takes much longer for me to find the files with GTK3 FileChooserDialog. But all of this has already been said.

Again, I wouldn't care if this was a Gnome-only issue, but your stance is affecting everybody if they happen to be using something based on GTK3. That is why you're getting so many issues about this, as show in the original message in this issue.

I urge you to reconsider accepting a merge requests that would add an option to bring the old behavior back.
